p.said: “ Now wash and dress yourselves. Here are two new suits of clothes — shirts, socks, everything complete. They’re Huck’s — no, no thanks, Huck — Mr. Jones bought one and I the other. But they’ll fit both of you. Get into them. We’ll wait — come down when you are slicked up enough. ”

div.p: Then she left.

div.head: Chapter XXXIV
div.note: The boys are getting ready the party at Widow Douglas' house, and Sid is being his usual mean self.
div.p:
HUCK said: “ Tom, we can slope, if we can find a rope. The window
ain’t isn’t
high from the ground.”

p.said: “ Shucks! what do you want to slope for?”

“Well, I
ain’t ’m not
used to that kind of a crowd. I can’t stand it. I
ain’t ’m not
going down there, Tom.”

“Oh, bother! It
ain’t ’s not
anything. I don’t mind it a bit. I’ll take care of you.”

div.p: Sid appeared.

“Tom,” said he, “auntie has been waiting for you all the afternoon. Mary got your Sunday clothes ready, and everybody’s been fretting about you. Say —
ain’t isn’t
this grease and clay, on your clothes?”

p.said:
“Now, Mr. Siddy, you
jist just
’tend attend
to your own business. What’s all this blow-out about, anyway?”

“ It’s one of the widow’s parties that she’s always having. This time it’s for the Welshman and his sons, on account of that scrape they helped her out of the other night. And say — I can tell you something, if you want to know.”
“Well, what?”

“Why, old Mr. Jones is going to try to spring something on the people here to-night, but I overheard him tell auntie to-day about it, as a secret, but I
reckon think
it’s not much of a secret now. Everybody knows — the widow, too, for all she tries to let on she
don’t doesn’t
. Mr. Jones was bound Huck should be here — couldn’t get along with his grand secret without Huck, you know!”
“Secret about what, Sid?”

“About Huck tracking the robbers to the widow’s. I
reckon think
Mr. Jones was going to make a grand time over his surprise, but I bet you it will drop pretty flat.”

p.seg: Sid chuckled in a very contented and satisfied way.

p.said: “Sid, was it you that told?”

said.seg: “Oh, never mind who it was. Somebody told — that’s enough.”

div.p:
“Sid, there’s only one person in this town mean enough to do that, and that’s you. If you had been in Huck’s place you
’d ‘a’ would have
sneaked down the hill and never told anybody on the robbers. You can’t do any but mean things, and you can’t bear to see anybody praised for doing good ones. There — no thanks, as the widow says” — and Tom cuffed Sid’s ears and helped him to the door with several kicks. “Now go and tell auntie if you dare — and to-morrow you’ll
catch it be punished
!”
div.note: The party reaches a climaxing point as important announcements are made.
div.p: Some minutes later the widow’s guests were at the supper-table, and a dozen children were propped up at little side-tables in the same room, after the fashion of that country and that day. At the proper time Mr. Jones made his little speech, in which he thanked the widow for the honor she was doing himself and his sons, but said that there was another person whose modesty —

And so forth and so on. He sprung his secret about Huck’s share in the adventure in the finest dramatic manner he was master of, but the surprise it occasioned was largely counterfeit and not as clamorous and effusive as it might have been under happier circumstances. However, the widow made a
pretty fair show of astonishment, and heaped so many compliments and so much gratitude upon Huck that he almost forgot the nearly intolerable discomfort of his new clothes in the entirely intolerable discomfort of being set up as a target for everybody’s gaze and everybody’s laudations.

The widow said she meant to give Huck a home under her roof and have him educated; and that when she could spare the money she would start him in business in a modest way. Tom’s chance
was come came
. He said:

p.said:
“Huck
don’t doesn’t
need it. Huck’s rich.”

div.p: Nothing but a heavy strain upon the good manners of the company kept back the due and proper complimentary laugh at this pleasant joke. But the silence was a little awkward. Tom broke it:

p.said:
“Huck’s got money. Maybe you don’t believe it, but he’s got lots of it. Oh, you needn’t smile — I
reckon think
I can show you. You just wait a minute.”

div.p: Tom ran out of doors. The company looked at each other with a perplexed interest — and inquiringly at Huck, who was tongue-tied.

“Sid, what ails Tom?” said Aunt Polly. “He — well, there
ain’t isn’t
ever any making of that boy out. I never —”
Tom entered, struggling with the weight of his sacks, and Aunt Polly did not finish her sentence. Tom poured the mass of yellow coin upon the table and said:

p.said: “There — what did I tell you? Half of it’s Huck’s and half of it’s mine!”

div.p: The spectacle took the general breath away. All gazed, nobody spoke for a moment. Then there was a unanimous call for an explanation. Tom said he could furnish it, and he did. The tale was long, but brimful of interest. There was scarcely an interruption from any one to break the charm of its flow. When he had finished, Mr. Jones said:

p.said:
“I thought I had fixed up a little surprise for this occasion, but it
don’t doesn’t
amount to anything now. This one makes it sing mighty small, I’m willing to allow.”

p.seg: The money was counted. The sum amounted to a little over twelve thousand dollars. The amount today would be in the range of 250 to 2.500 thousand $ It was more than any one present had ever seen at one time before, though several persons were there who were worth considerably more than that in property.

div.head: Chapter XXXV
div.note: The village is once again agitated and the fate of the newly-wealthy heroes is being planned.
div.p:
THE reader may rest satisfied that Tom’s and Huck’s windfall made a mighty stir in the poor little village of St. Petersburg. So vast a sum, all in actual cash, seemed next to incredible. It was talked about, gloated over, glorified, until the reason of many of the citizens tottered under the strain of the unhealthy excitement. Every “haunted” house in St. Petersburg and the neighboring villages was dissected, plank by plank, and its foundations dug up and ransacked for hidden treasure — and not by boys, but men — pretty grave, unromantic men, too, some of them. Wherever Tom and Huck appeared they were courted, admired, stared at. The boys were not able to remember that their remarks had possessed weight before; but now their sayings were treasured and repeated; everything they did seemed somehow to be regarded
as remarkable; they had evidently lost the power of doing and saying commonplace things; moreover, their past history was raked up and discovered to bear marks of conspicuous originality. The village paper published biographical sketches of the boys.

The Widow Douglas put Huck’s money out at six per cent., and Judge Thatcher did the same with Tom’s at Aunt Polly’s request. Each lad had an income, now, that was simply prodigious — a dollar for every week-day in the year and half of the Sundays. It was just what the minister got — no, it was what he was promised — he generally couldn’t collect it. A dollar and a quarter a week would board, lodge, and school a boy in those old simple days — and clothe him and wash him, too, for that matter.

Judge Thatcher had conceived a great opinion of Tom. He said that no commonplace boy would ever have got his daughter out of the cave. When Becky told her father, in strict confidence, how Tom had taken her whipping at school, the Judge was visibly moved; and when she pleaded grace for the mighty lie which Tom had told in order to shift that whipping from her shoulders to his own, the Judge said with a fine outburst that it was a noble, a generous, a magnanimous lie — a lie that was worthy to hold up its head and march down through history breast to breast with George Washington’s lauded Truth about the hatchet! Becky thought her father had never looked so tall and so superb as when he walked the floor and stamped his foot and said that. She went straight off and told Tom about it.

p.seg: Judge Thatcher hoped to see Tom a great lawyer or a great soldier some day. He said he meant to look to it that Tom should be admitted to the National Military Academy and afterward trained in the best law school in the country, in order that he might be ready for either career or both.

div.note: Huck, now under the wing of Mrs. Douglas, is currently feeling suffocated by social norms.

p.seg:
Huck Finn’s wealth and the fact that he was now under the Widow Douglas’s protection introduced him into society — no, dragged him into it, hurled him into it — and his sufferings were almost more than he could bear. The widow’s servants kept him clean and neat, combed and brushed, and they bedded him nightly in unsympathetic sheets that had not one little spot or stain which he could press to his heart and know for a friend. He had to eat with a knife and
fork; he had to use napkin, cup, and plate; he had to learn his book, he had to go to church; he had to talk so properly that speech was become insipid in his mouth; whithersoever he turned, the bars and shackles of civilization shut him in and bound him hand and foot.

div.p:
After trying to adapt to a new environment, Huck goes missing everyone apart from Tom is unable to locate him. He bravely bore his miseries three weeks, and then one day turned up missing. For forty-eight hours the widow hunted for him everywhere in great distress. The public were profoundly concerned; they searched high and low, they dragged the river for his body. Early the third morning
Tom Sawyer wisely went poking among some old empty hogsheads down behind the abandoned slaughter-house, and in one of them he found the refugee. Huck had slept there; he had just breakfasted upon some stolen odds and ends of food, and was lying off, now, in comfort, with his pipe. He was unkempt, uncombed, and clad in the same old ruin of rags that had made him picturesque in the days when he was free and happy. Tom routed him out, told him the trouble he had been causing, and urged him to go home. Huck’s face lost its tranquil content, and took a melancholy cast. He said:

said.seg:
“Don’t talk about it, Tom. I’ve tried it, and it
don’t doesn’t
work; it
don’t doesn’t
work, Tom. It
ain’t ’s not
for me; I
ain’t ’m not
used to it.

The
widder widdow
’s good to me, and friendly; but I can’t stand
them those
ways. She makes me get up just at the same time every morning; she makes me wash, they comb me
all to thunder all to hell
; she won’t let me sleep in the woodshed; I
got have got
to wear
them those
blamed damned
clothes that just
smothers smother
me, Tom;
they there
don’t doesn’t
seem to any air
git get
through
’em them
, somehow; and they’re so rotten nice that I can’t
set sit
down, nor lay down, nor roll around
anywher’s anywhere
; I
hain’t haven’t
slid on a cellar-door for — well, it
’pears to appears to
be years; I
got have got
to go to church and sweat and sweat — I hate
them those
ornery sermons! I can’t
ketch catch
a fly in there, I can’t
chaw chew
. I
got have got
to wear shoes all Sunday. The
widder widdow
eats by a bell; she goes to bed by a bell; she
gits gets
up by a bell — everything’s so awful
reg’lar regular
a body can’t stand it.”
“Well, everybody does that way, Huck.”

“Tom, it
don’t doesn’t
make no difference. I
ain’t ’m not
everybody, and I can’t stand it. It’s awful to be tied up so. And
grub food
comes too easy — I don’t take no interest in vittles, that way. I
got have got
to ask to go
a-fishing fishing
; I
got have got
to ask to go in
a-swimming swimming
—
dern’d damned
if I
hain’t haven’t
got to ask to do everything. Well, I’d got to talk so nice it wasn’t
no any
comfort — I’d got to go up in the attic and
rip out swear
awhile, every day, to
git get
a taste in my mouth, or I
’d a would
died, Tom. The
widder widdow
wouldn’t let me smoke; she wouldn’t let me yell, she wouldn’t let me gape, nor stretch, nor scratch, before folks —” [Then with a spasm of special irritation and injury] — “And
dad fetch it damn it
, she prayed all the time! I never see such a woman! I had to shove, Tom — I just had to. And besides, that school’s going to open, and I
’d a would have
had to go to it — well, I wouldn’t stand that, Tom.
Looky-here Look here
, Tom, being rich
ain’t isn’t
what it’s
cracked up praised
to be. It’s just worry and worry, and sweat and sweat, and
cracked up praised
a-wishing wishing
you
was were
dead all the time. Now these clothes
suits suit
me, and this
bar’l barrel
suits me, and I
ain’t ever ’m never
going to
shake leave
’em them
any more. Tom, I wouldn’t ever got into all this trouble if it
hadn’t 'a' ben had not been
for that money; now you just take my sheer of it along with
your’n yours
, and
gimme give me
a ten-center sometimes — not many times,
becuz because
I
don’t give a
dern damn
for a thing
’thout although
it’s
tollable incomparable
hard to
git get
— and you go and beg off for me with the
widder widdow
.”

“Oh, Huck, you know I can’t do that.
’Tain’t It’s not
fair; and besides if you’ll try this thing just a while longer you’ll come to like it.”

p.said:
“Like it! Yes — the way I’d like a hot stove
if I was if I were
to
set sit
on it long enough. No, Tom, I won’t be rich, and I won’t live in
them those
cussed smothery houses. I like the woods, and the river, and hogsheads, and I’ll stick to
’em them
, too.
Blame Damn
it all! just as we’d got guns, and a cave, and all just fixed to rob, here this
dern damn
foolishness has got to come up and
spile spoil
it all!”

div.note: Tom uses his wit to convince Huck to stay with Mrs. Douglas and become a prominent member of the society.
div.p: Tom saw his opportunity —

said.seg:
“
Lookyhere Look here
, Huck, being rich
ain’t isn’t
going to keep me back from turning robber.”

p.said:
“No! Oh,
good-licks good
; are you in
real dead-wood really
earnest, Tom?”

“Just as dead earnest as I’m sitting here. But Huck, we can’t let you into the gang if you
ain’t ’re not
respectable, you know.”

div.p: Huck’s joy was quenched.

p.said: “Can’t let me in, Tom? Didn’t you let me go for a pirate?”

said.seg:
“Yes, but that’s different. A robber is more high-toned than what a pirate is — as a general thing. In most countries they’re
awful very
high up in the nobility — dukes and such.”

p.said:
“ Now, Tom,
ain’t haven’t
you always
ben been
friendly to me? You wouldn’t
shet shut
me out, would you, Tom? You wouldn’t do that, now, would you, Tom?”

said.seg: “Huck, I wouldn’t want to, and I don’t want to — but what would people say? Why, they’d say, ‘Mph! Tom Sawyer’s Gang! pretty low characters in it!’ They’d mean you, Huck. You wouldn’t like that, and I wouldn’t.”

div.p: Huck was silent for some time, engaged in a mental struggle. Finally he said:

said.seg:
“Well, I’ll go back to the
widder widdow
for a month and tackle it and see if I can come to stand it, if you’ll let me
b’long belong
to the gang, Tom.”

p.said:
“All right, Huck,
it’s a whiz it’s easy
! Come along, old chap, and I’ll ask the widow to let up on you a little, Huck.”

said.seg: “Will you, Tom — now will you? That’s good. If she’ll let up on some of the roughest things, I’ll smoke private and cuss private, and crowd through or bust. When you going to start the gang and turn robbers?”
“Oh, right off. We’ll get the boys together and have the initiation to-night, maybe.”

p.said: “Have the which?”
“Have the initiation.”
“What’s that?”

said.seg:
“It’s to swear to stand by one another, and never tell the gang’s secrets, even if you’re chopped all to
flinders splinters
, and kill anybody and all his family that hurts one of the gang.”

p.said: “That’s gay — that’s mighty gay, Tom, I tell you.”

seg.seg:
“Well, I bet it is. And all that swearing’s got to be done at midnight, in the lonesomest, awfulest place you can find — a
ha’nted haunted
house is the best, but they’re all ripped up now.”

p.said: “Well, midnight’s good, anyway, Tom.”

said.seg: “Yes, so it is. And you’ve got to swear on a coffin, and sign it with blood.”

“Now, that’s something like! Why, it’s a million times
bullier greater
than pirating. I’ll stick to the
widder widdow
till I rot, Tom; and if I
git get
to be a
reg’lar regular
ripper of a excellent
robber, and everybody talking
’bout about
it, I
reckon think
she’ll be proud she
snaked dragged
me in out of the wet.”

div.note: This was the story of the boy named Tom Sawyer.
div.head: CONCLUSION

p.seg: SO endeth this chronicle. It being strictly a history of a boy, it must stop here; the story could not go much further without becoming the history of a man. When one writes a novel about grown people, he knows exactly where to stop — that is, with a marriage; but when he writes of juveniles, he must stop where he best can.

Most of the characters that perform in this book still live, and are prosperous and happy. Some day it may seem worth while to take up the story of the younger ones again and see what sort of men and women they turned out to be; therefore it will be wisest not to reveal any of that part of their lives at present.
